captions.text: What the hell are you doing to my car?

Hey, beat it, spook.
This don't concern you.

...I don't want to mess
with no reefer addicts, okay?
MARVIN: Get home to your mama, boy.
MARTY: [Muffled] Let me out of here!
MARTY: [Muffled] The keys are in the trunk.

MARVIN: Say that again?
MARTY: I said, the keys are in here.
Hey you, get your damn hands off...
I think you got the wrong car, McFly.
Just turn around, McFly, and walk away.

LORRAINE: Please, George.
BIFF: Are you deaf?
BIFF: Close the door and beat it.
No, Biff. You leave her alone.
...and now you're going to get it.
MARVIN: Give me a hand here, Reginald.
Damn it, man! I sliced my hand!
You're going to break his arm!
Let him go! Let him go!

title: Back to the Future (8/10) Movie CLIP - You Leave Her Alone (1985) HD

comments.text:
The sound of the tremble in his voice when he says, "No, Biff. You leave 
her alone," -- and he is clearly Not Going Anywhere -- still makes me well 
up 30 years later. Crispin Glover may have been a weirdo on set but he 
dominates every scene he's in.﻿
comments.author: a35362

comments.text:
Back to the Future 2 undermines this scene. We see Biff spike the punch 
that George drinks from. While there is the irony of Biff contributing to 
his own demise it is more satisfying to believe that Biff's actions were 
solely his own.﻿

My mom once adopted a puppy around Halloween time.  She wanted to name it 
something Halloween themed and was considering Spooky, but then she had 
images of the dog getting lost and her husband (who is one of the most 
Guido looking people you could imagine) running around the neighborhood 
shouting "Hey Spook!  C'mere Spook!" and someone replying "Who you calling 
spook, peckerwood?"  No bullshit. ﻿

comments.author: Quinnzel

comments.text:
One point I'd like to add..  These are great movies just like so many from 
the 80's because every single one of them has this incredible melody that 
runs throughout them. It's repeated in many forms; some big & adventurous, 
some like this where it's fervent & sweet. I cannot list the million things 
wrong with movies today, but I believe this vital aspect is missing. And 
films shall never gain the value that these films have because of it.
Sometimes I dream for a day where Film, Music & TV are restored to their 
perfection so we can have more greater classics like this. But I know that 
will never happen as long as people continue to fear individuality.

The next time you jump on Netflix or Love Film, do yourself favour & watch 
a film from the 80's - there's SO many classics. And once you've watched 
them all, watch the 70's, & then the 60's, & then the 90's! Anything but 
the post 2000's where everything is made cheap, Fake, & disposable.﻿
comments.author: KINDLE

comments.text:
+Imperial Dutchman
lol A Clockwork Orange is a masterpiece! I watched it only a month ago & 
holds up better than most films.

Nostalgia is irrational Yeh! He He! Though I wasn't around at the time of 
James Bond, Jaws, BTTF, Superman, Batman, The Good The Bad & the Ugly, etc. 
I can look back in wonder & compare it to today. Hans Zimmer's The Dark 
knight just didn't captivate me like Danny Elfman did with that stunning 
opening motif & the march.
I have noticed that in recent years, scores have been infested with "feral 
percussion". I don't mind it in films like Gladiator, Lord of the 
Ringholes, 300, etc. Ya know..  Epics! But it's in every...  single..  
fucking...  film now! lol

The trouble with this, is composers cease to compose, & merely conform to 
what the latest fads in music are. It takes a great musician & artist to go 
against the "epic loud drums" trope & create a truly memorable score.

"So why don't you show us how it's done then?" - a natural question I get 
asked!
The Trouble is that those with the financial comfort of infiltrating the 
music industry with degrees in theory don't have the struggles & pain 
required to write meaningful music. Have you never wondered why it's only 
high classed white men that succeed?!
However, if you're interested in what I'm worth artistically, put this into 
Google: "Á Svartur Staður soundcloud". My Science Fiction Theme Project 
demonstrates my love of melody. Of course, you have to try & imagine it 
replicated as a magnificent Orchestral plethora! I don't have the funding 
to do that so used electronics. :_( Sigh. God I feel trapped out.
comments.author: KINDLE

comments.text:
+KINDLE I see. I have heard of Clockwork Orange's initial reception, but 
you mention it as a stinker (instead of saying that the audience at the 
time thought it was a stinker). I therefore thought that you actually 
consider it a bad movie. 

It's good that you acknowledge the films you have mentioned. That shows 
that you are not just suffering from nostalgia. Your main pet peeve is the 
lack of recognisable musical scores since the year 2000, but what about 
films like Lord of the Rings, Pirates of the Caribbean or Harry Potter? 
They have recognisable musical scores too. Ask someone to whistle the music 
played in the Shire, and they'll know it just as likely as the theme to 
BTTF. A more recent example of a film with a highly recognisable soundtrack 
would be that of The Dark Knight (a comic book hero-story, I know, but I 
would argue that Nolan's version of Batman is more of a crime drama than a 
Marvel cartoon-esque superhero flick). 

However, you are completely right about the overuse of CGI. Ironically, I 
think the only movie to do a good job of writing a story to show off 
special effects was the original Avatar. Nevertheless, I too do not see the 
need for two sequels: Avatar was an enjoyable gimmick, not an epic. Peter 
Jackson's The Hobbit, which could have been another landmark series of 
films, was sadly ruined by an over-emphasis on CGI (among other things).  
That does not mean that worthwhile films aren't being produced on a regular 
basis, though. 2014 was actually a pretty damn good year for films IMO, 
though Hollywood appears to be producing less of them.
comments.author: Imperial Dutchman

comments.text:
+Imperial Dutchman
A Clockwork Orange was considered a flop upon release as everyone 
misunderstood it at the time; Stanley withdrew it eventually. It wasn't 
until his demise that the world reassessed it's true introspective merits & 
black humour. At the time, the world was not ready for an electric score, & 
despised it.

There have been some masterpieces yes. Pan's Labyrinth, Oldboy, Zatoichi, 
Downfall, City of God to name a few non hollywood flicks. But until they 
stop wrapping pointless storylines around visual effects, it will be...  as 
you say yourself....  a product of the times. It becomes dated very quickly.

A great film however is "Time-Less".
But hey! Maybe I'm wrong & we DO need another 2 Avatar films?! pmsl
comments.author: KINDLE

comments.text:
+KINDLE Clockwork Orange is a stinker? Really? I must have missed something 
there. 
I think that it's quite sad that you think that there have been nothing but 
bad films or film scores since the early 2000s. I personally disagree fully 
with that, even from a musical perspective. Films have just changed, is 
all. They've moved along with the times. Sure there have been awful films 
in recent years, but the eighties definitely had those too.
comments.author: Imperial Dutchman

comments.text:
+David Mitchell
Not at all. I remember some stinkers like Return to OZ, Flight of the 
Navigator, TM (Too Much), A Clockwork Orange, John Barry's Bonds, Candyman 
etc. Most of which are somewhat of an embarrassment now! But even the shit 
scores to questionable films had melodic value within their cues.

Today's' films all have this generic epic feral drum crap to them whether 
it's a low budget film or a high-end Hans Zimmer production. I recall "The 
Good, Bad & Ugly" was composed on the cheap & thus coerced creative 
solutions on the composer's part. You don't get long protracted wide shots 
of scenery like birds flying off into the sunset now. There's no patience, 
focus or depth to cinematography.

We had a brief peek with the Chinese fad in the early 2000s with Crouching 
Tiger', House of Flying Daggers, etc. But it's all frenetic slop lately. 
Directors are afraid of melody.
In fact, I'd go as far to say that computer game scores have excelled in 
recent years.
comments.author: KINDLE

comments.text:
The thing is, you are only remembering the great ones. There were plenty of 
shit movies made back then too. In 30 years time, we will look back on this 
decade and remember some of the greats, but will have forgotten about the 
crappy ones
comments.author: David Mitchell

comments.text:
+GothicHand
Please don't compare a cult trilogy like BTTF to kids cartoon cgi flicks. 
Marvel & all the other comic-strip adaptations of late might as well just 
be labelled "generic" & have done with. If I go up to a random stranger in 
the street, & ask them to humm for me 3 "themes" from marvel films, they'd 
look lost. But if I ask them to humm a line from Terminator, Jaws, From 
Russia with Love, Merry Poppins, Star Wars, The Sound of Music etc. It's 
not always the "theme" they remember exclusively. So yes..  I believe music 
should have melodies in more than just the themes. And they suck now by 
comparison.
comments.author: KINDLE

comments.text:
That "incredible melody" is call a Theme. And I can assure you many films 
still has them, because it is a very effective way of film scoring. In 
fact, all the recent Marvel films does, the music styles is certainly 
different, but it's the same mechanic.
comments.author: GothicHand

comments.author: qwert9876

comments.text:
It was to show that George was a timid nerd. And after the circumstances 
changed where Marty was out of the way, with his biggest fear the cowardly 
bully Biff for real trying to date rape Lorraine, that he couldn't step 
away. This was his one chance to save her. George faced his fear. And 
FINALLY conquered it by laying off Biff & rescuing Lorraine.
Interestingly, this wasn't even in the first Draft of BTTF, instead, Biff 
was forcing Lorraine to go out with him while George cowered away. At the 
Dance scene, George finally stands up after being taunted by Biff and 
shoves him to the ground.

It was re-written for the "Parking Lot" scene" for GOOD reason. So that 
there could be better storytelling.

gets bled out. It's all super cynical, look how flawlessly cool these 
characters are, or check out this awesome choreography, with bland story 
telling rife with inauthenticity. Pretty much the only decent movies of the 
past 5-10 years have been the cartoon ones.

comments.text:
+gameaddict51 Actually in one scene Doc explains it as the "Florence 
Nightingale Effect," which I believe is actually a real psychological 
phenomenon.  Its sort of a nurturing instinct thing and is best exemplified 
by doctors or nurses falling in love with their patients.

comments.author: Zain844

comments.text:
Actually in the earlier draft of BTTF, there's a scene written where George 
practices with a laundry bag and somehow mulls a left hook knocking it 
down. Bob Gale and Robert Zemeckis decided to delete it, because they 
figured it would be better to just surprise the audience when he finally 
stood up to Biff.
comments.author: Tornado1994

comments.author: Gábor Bankó

comments.text:
Of maybe Biff was a bigger wimp than he let on, which is perhaps why he

comments.author: Daniel Ryan

comments.text:
Some people don't truly know what they are capable until they are pushed to 
their breaking point. Mcfly always had great physical strength but because 
he had such low self confidence he let everyone push him around. He was not 
physically weak, (as demonstrated by knocking out Biff and later 
effortlessly pushing another man to the ground when he was trying to steal 
his woman in the dance) he was mentally weak. He had no self confidence was 
scared of rejection etc. A lot of the times people get bullied not because 
they are weak, but because they are too scared to fight back.
comments.author: Zain844

comments.text:
I remember watching this movie when it first came out.  I was with a buddy 
who practiced tae kwon do, and I remember him cheering under his breath at 
that moment when he saw George's face transform, and he said "YES. Total 
commitment."  When I asked him about it later he said that this was the 
key, to commit completely and not hold anything back.  He said that was how 
George beat Biff in one punch.  Interesting.
comments.author: grayfoxfive
